creator: Hub MakerSpace
title: Lampara en forma de piña
materials_required: Palo de bambú o un tubo pvc del ancho de la boca de la botella con un largo de 30 cm
Mecha fina para fabricación de circuitos (para dremel)
description: This is an eco-friendly version of a lamp made from objects that are often discarded without considering their potential uses. The project involves creating a pineapple-shaped lamp using a plastic bottle, plastic spoons, and an electronic circuit to control the light.
steps: Cut the bottom and top of the plastic bottle, then attach the top part to the body using silicone.
Paint the plastic spoons yellow, from the widest part to the handle, and cut off the painted part.
Attach the painted spoons to the bottle using a silicone gun, reinforcing the joints with liquid silicone.
Glue the bamboo or PVC pipe to the inside center of the tuna can using a silicone gun and let it cool.
Prepare plaster and pour it into the can with the bamboo or pipe, then wait for it to dry.

Cut the cardboard into different sizes and shapes to create the bow. Also cut a strip where the sheets will be glued. After gluing them, roll them a little and release them so that this natural curved effect is created as seen in the second image.
Program the PIC microcontroller using mikroC PRO for PIC software and transfer the program using mikroProg suite for Pic and the pickit programmer.

Fabricate the circuit by printing the circuit design on glossy paper, sanding the bakelite board with fine sandpaper, and placing the circuit on the copper side. Apply heat with an iron for 10 minutes, then immerse in water and remove the paper with a needle.

Mix muriatic acid (70%) and hydrogen peroxide (30%) in a plastic container to cover the bakelite board. Submerge the board and move until only the black lines remain. Remove with tweezers and discard the liquid with plenty of water.
Sand the bakelite board until the tracks are shiny and free of black color.
Drill holes in the bakelite board at the designated points using a drill and a fine drill bit.
Mount the components on the non-copper side of the perforated bakelite board, starting with the smallest components, and solder them using a soldering iron and solder.

Make a hole in the top of the bottle to pass the switch and push button. Solder wires to the switch and push button and solder them to the bakelite board. Glue the circuit to the bottle cap and the battery holder with the battery to the side.
Attach the bamboo or PVC pipe to the inside of the lamp shade (bottle cap) using hot silicone and liquid silicone for extra security. Secure the push button and switch with tape.
Attach the bow with liquid silicone. Turn on the lamp using the switch and vary the light intensity using the push button.
